messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: Unlike many other famous album (music collection) artists, Springsteen (famous American singer) is still making hit, stadium (large sport area) concerts with new songs. He is also very good at his work in his late 60s. I am not surprised. Springsteen is a man who tells us important stories about people. When you listen to Born in the USA (Springsteen album), these stories are still important today.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL. Fidelity breaches: 'is still making hit, stadium concerts with new songs' replaces 'releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music' with concerts; this adds concerts and drops the core idea of releasing chart-topping new music. 'famous album (music collection) artists' weakens 'best-selling album artists' and loses the sales fact. 'important stories about people' changes 'our most fundamental stories about ourselves' (drops 'most' and 'ourselves'). Form issues: Sentence 1 has 24 words—too long for B1. Sentence 5 has 16 words—over the target. 'making ... concerts' is an unnatural collocation that hurts clarity. Vocabulary/keywords: Required keywords are defined once ('Springsteen', 'Born in the USA')—OK. Unneeded parenthetical definitions ('album (music collection)', 'stadium (large sport area)') bloat the text. Cohesion is basic and acceptable, but the factual shifts and length issues outweigh this.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen (famous American singer) releases chart-topping and stadium-filling new music. He remains at the top of his game in his late 60s. I am not surprised. This is a man who tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves. When you listen to Born in the USA (Springsteen album), these stories remain relevant today.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: Fidelity breach. 'is still making hit, stadium (large sport area) concerts with new songs' changes 'still releasing chart-topping, stadium-filling new music' to concerts. This shifts meaning from releasing popular new music to performing concerts. Lexis/grammar: mostly B1, but sentence 1 is 24 words (too long) and cluttered with multiple parenthetical inserts; sentence 5 has 16 words (over target). Phrasing 'hit, stadium concerts' is awkward and unclear. Cohesion is simple and fine. Keywords: 'Springsteen (famous American singer)' and 'Born in the USA (Springsteen album)' are briefly defined—acceptable. However, extra definitions for 'album (music collection)' and 'stadium (large sport area)' are unnecessary and inflate complexity. Minor nuance loss: 'as relevant today as they ever were' becomes 'still important today' (weaker meaning). Due to the key factual shift and length violations, this does not meet strict B1 criteria.

However, the factual deviations and length issues outweigh positives.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: Unlike many other best-selling album artists, Springsteen (famous American singer) is still releasing new music. His music tops charts and fills stadiums. He is at the top of his game in his late 60s. I am not surprised at all. He tells us our most fundamental stories about ourselves. When you listen to Born in the USA (Springsteen album), his stories are still relevant.
Feedback received: Grade 6/10 - PASS

metadata.feedback_text: Mixed B1 control. Keywords defined correctly: “Springsteen (famous American singer)” and “Born in the USA (Springsteen album)”. However, the first sentence is too long and cluttered: “Unlike many other famous album (music collection) artists, Springsteen (famous American singer) is still making hit, stadium (large sport area) concerts with new songs.” (~24 words, multiple parentheses). Fidelity issues: The original states he is “still releasing … new music”; you changed it to “still making … concerts,” which shifts from releasing music to performing shows. “Hit concerts” misrepresents “chart-topping” (charts measure songs/albums, not concerts). Another fidelity drift: “stories about ourselves” became “stories about people,” losing the first-person focus. Grammar/lexis are mostly B1 and simple in other sentences (“I am not surprised.”, “He is also very good at his work in his late 60s.”). Connectors are simple. Overall pass, but penalized for the long, complex first sentence and the meaning shifts.
